page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

==January==
==January==
===25 January â Day of Revolt===
===25 January â Day of Revolt===
â
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching to [[Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held]]
+
{{multiple image
  +
| width1 = 170
  +
| width2 = 170

| align =
  +
| footer = From left to right: Protesters marching to [[Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held; and Paramilitary riot police of the [[Central Security Forces]]; 20000 to 30000 police were deployed in central Cairo.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110125-egyptian-protesters-say-tunisia-solution |title=Egyptian protesters say Tunisia is the solution |publisher=RFI |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
  +

On 25 January 2011, known as the "'''Day of Revolt'''" ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|yawm al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'', {{IPA-arz|ËjoËm elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref name="ERSAFVZSD" /> or the '''"Day of Anger"''',<ref name="bbc25jan" /> protests took place in cities across Egypt, including [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[IsmaÃ¯lia]].<ref name="bbc25jan" /> The day was selected as such by the ''[[6 April Youth Movement]]'', ''We Are All Khaled Said Movement'', ''[[National Association for Change]]'', ''25 January Movement'' and ''[[Kefaya]]''<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{Cite news|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|coauthors=El-Nagaar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule|work=The New York Times | date=25 January 2011| accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/301058|title=6 April movement calls for protest against police abuse |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> to coincide with [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. Thousands protested in Cairo, with 15,000 occupying [[Tahrir Square]]<ref name="ERSAFVZSD">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48cxf|archivedate=2011-01-29|title=Egyptians Report Poor Communication Services on Day of Anger|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> (Liberation Square), 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Manthorpe, Jonathan|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians Test Tunisia's Twitter Revolution|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> 200 demonstrators in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2,000 in the eastern city of IsmaÃ¯lia, and about 3,000 in the northern city of [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Ahmed, Amir|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
On 25 January 2011, known as the "'''Day of Revolt'''" ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|yawm al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'', {{IPA-arz|ËjoËm elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref name="ERSAFVZSD" /> or the '''"Day of Anger"''',<ref name="bbc25jan" /> protests took place in cities across Egypt, including [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[IsmaÃ¯lia]].<ref name="bbc25jan" /> The day was selected as such by the ''[[6 April Youth Movement]]'', ''We Are All Khaled Said Movement'', ''[[National Association for Change]]'', ''25 January Movement'' and ''[[Kefaya]]''<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{Cite news|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|coauthors=El-Nagaar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule|work=The New York Times | date=25 January 2011| accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/301058|title=6 April movement calls for protest against police abuse |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> to coincide with [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. Thousands protested in Cairo, with 15,000 occupying [[Tahrir Square]]<ref name="ERSAFVZSD">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48cxf|archivedate=2011-01-29|title=Egyptians Report Poor Communication Services on Day of Anger|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> (Liberation Square), 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Manthorpe, Jonathan|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians Test Tunisia's Twitter Revolution|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> 200 demonstrators in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2,000 in the eastern city of IsmaÃ¯lia, and about 3,000 in the northern city of [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Ahmed, Amir|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
â   â
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|Paramilitary riot police of the [[Central Security Forces]]; 20,000 to 30,000 police were deployed in central Cairo.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110125-egyptian-protesters-say-tunisia-solution |title=Egyptian protesters say Tunisia is the solution |publisher=RFI |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> ]]
 
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo. The demonstration was larger than expected. It broke through the security cordon and moved to [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=\ArabicAndInter\2011\01\ArabicAndInter_issue1200_day27_id299121.htm |title=3 ÙØªÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ± |work=Al Dustour |language=Arabic |date= 27 January 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> Police used [[tear gas]] and [[water cannon]]s against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan" /> It was reported that many police had limited their use of force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo. The demonstration was larger than expected. It broke through the security cordon and moved to [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=\ArabicAndInter\2011\01\ArabicAndInter_issue1200_day27_id299121.htm |title=3 ÙØªÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ± |work=Al Dustour |language=Arabic |date= 27 January 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> Police used [[tear gas]] and [[water cannon]]s against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan" /> It was reported that many police had limited their use of force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
